text.p: Diversified mining and engineering group Ticor Ltd said on Monday it expected its profit for the full calendar 1996 year would be significantly worse than previously indicated because of delays in increasing synthetic rutile output and weak titanium dioxide pigment prices.

"Ticor Group financial results for 1996 are now expected to be significantly worse than indicated at the half year due to the commissioning of the increased synthetic rutile capacity taking longer than planned and titanium dioxide pigment prices deteriorating further," Ticor said.

It also said that the upgrade of its 50 percent joint venture synthetic rutile plant at Chandala in Western Australia had been completed and was now operating at the rate of of 183,000 tonnes per annum.
Previous capacity of the synthetic rutile at Chandala was 160,000 tonnes a year.
In August Ticor reported a A$9.99 million net loss for the first six months of 1996, worse than the prospectus forecast.
Ticor said then that the final six months of the year should show positive earnings.
Ticor's shares closed unchanged at A$1.08.
